abstractText: We define game semantics for the constructive μ-calculus and prove its correctness. We use these game semantics to prove that the μ-calculus collapses to modal logic over CS5 frames. Finally, we prove the completeness of μCS5 over CS5 frames.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text:
This paper is a first step into relating two strands of research modal logic: the µ-calculus and constructive modal logics. We define a constructive version of the µ-calculus by adding fixed-point operators to constructive modal logic. We base our semantics on the bi-relational Kripke semantics of Wijesekera [Wij90] (but we allow fallible worlds in our models). We define game semantics for the constructive µ-calculus and prove its equivalence to the bi-relational Kripke semantics.
The main advantage of game semantics for the µ-calculus is that they allow for easier comprehension of the µ-formulas, which are famously hard to understand. In an evaluation game for the classical µ-calculus, the players Verifier and Refuter discuss whether a formula holds at a given world of a Kripke model. In an evaluation game for the constructive µ-calculus, we still have two players, but they alternate between the roles of Verifier and Refuter depending on their choices. This happens because every formulas can be put in negative normal form over classical semantics, which allows for these simpler evaluation games. Therefore we need a more delicate argument to prove the equivalence of the semantics in the constructive case compared to the classical case. Our proof is based on the proof of the correctness of game semantics for the classical µ-calculus by Ong [Ong15].
For applications, we study the logic µCS5, a constructive variation of S5 with the addition of fixed-points. We first use the game semantics to show that the (constructive) µ-calculus collapses to (constructive) modal logic over CS5 frames. That is, every formula with fixed-point operators is equivalent to a formula without fixed-point operators over CS5 frames. The CS5 frames are a subclass of the bi-relational CS4 frames defined in Alechina et al. [Ale+01]; we require that the modal accessibility relation of the CS5 frames is an equivalence relation. Our proof is a generalization of Alberucci and Facchini’s proof of the collapse of the (classical) µ-calculus to (classical) modal logic over S5 frames.
Note that this collapse does not happen in general. Over arbitrary frames, we have a strict alternation hierarchy, with formulas which are not equivalent to any other formula with less fixed-point alternation.
We use the µ-calculus’ collapse to modal logic over CS5 frames to prove the completeness of µCS5 over CS5 frames. The modal logic µCS5 is obtained by adding fixed-point axioms and rules to the modal logic CS5. As far as the author is aware, this is the first completeness proof for a system over the constructive µ-calculus. We also describe how to use our methods to prove the completeness of µIS5 and µGS5 over IS5 and GS5 frames, respectively. The logic µIS5 is obtained by adding fixed-point operators to IS5, an intuitionistic variant of S5. IS5 is also known as MIPQ. An IS5 frame is a CS5 frame with no fallible worlds. The completeness of IS5 over IS5 frames is already known [Ono77; Fis78] The logic µGS5 is obtained by adding fixed-point operators to GS5, a variation of S5 over real-valued semantics.
We now briefly review the related literature on the µ-calculus and constructive modal logics. The µ-calculus was defined by Kozen [Koz83], who also defined a related proof system µK. The completeness of µK was first proved by Walukiewicz [Wal95]. See [Len10; BW18] for surveys on the µ-calculus.
The µ-calculus’ alternation hierarchy classifies the µ-formulas by how many alternating least and greatest fixed-point operators they contain. The strictness of the hierarchy was open for many years until it was proved by Bradfield [Bra98b]. Bradfield later gave a simplified proof of the alternation hierarchy’s strictness using evaluation games [Bra98a]. The strictness may not hold over restricted classes of frames. For example, Alberucci and Facchini [AF09] proved that the alternation hierarchy collapses to its alternation-free fragment over transitive frames, and to modal logic over equivalence relations. See Chapter 2 of [Pac23] for a survey on the alternation hierarchy.
On a constructive modal logic, the duality of the modalities and ♦ is lost. These logics have been studied for a long time; some of the first texts on the topic are Fitch [Fit48] and Prawitz [Pra06]. We base our Kripke models over Wijesekera [Wij90], who defined a constructive modal logic CK and proved its completeness over CK frames. The difference between Wijesekera’s CK frames and our bi-relational frames is that we allow fallible worlds. On fallible worlds, the false proposition ⊥ holds. The logic CK was also studied by Acclavio et al. [ACS21]; they define and prove the correctness of a validity game for CK. See [Gie22; Sim94] for surveys on constructive modal logic.
The modal logic CS5 studied in this paper is closely related to the modal logic MIPQ, an intuitionistic variant of S5. MIPQ is also known as IS5, and was first studied by Prawitz [Pra06]. The completeness of IS5 over IS5 frames was proved by Ono [Ono77] and Fischer Servi [Fis78]. The logic GS5 was studied by Caicedo et al. [Cai+13], who proved its completeness over real-valued S5 models.
Outline In Section 2, we define the syntax and bi-relational Kripke semantics for the constructive µ-calculus. We also define the modal logics CS5 and µCS5, and the class of CS5 frames. In Section 3, we define the game semantics for the constructive µ-calculus and prove its equivalence to Kripke semantics. In Section 4, we prove the constructive µ-calculus’ collapse to modal logic over CS5 frames. In Section 5, we prove the completeness of µCS5 over CS5 frames.
We also describe how to prove completeness results for µIS5 and µGS5.
Acknowledgements I would like to thank David Fernández-Duque, Iris van der Giessen, and Konstantinos Papafilippou for the discussions we had about constructive modal logics and the µ-calculus. This research was partially funded by the FWF grant TAI-797.

sections.heading: 2.1 Constructive µ-calculus
sections.text:
Syntax The language of the µ-calculus is obtained by adding least and greatest fixed-point operators µ and ν to the language of modal logic. When defining the fixed-point formulas µX.ϕ and νX.ϕ, we will require that the variable symbol X is positive in ϕ; we will need to do so in order to have well-behaved semantics. We will describe when a variable is positive after we describe a grammar generating the µ-formulas.
Fix a set Prop of proposition symbols and a set Var of variable symbols. The constructive µ-formulas are defined by the following grammar:
ϕ := P | X | ⊥ | ⊤ | ¬ϕ | ϕ ∧ ϕ | ϕ ∨ ϕ | ϕ→ ϕ | ϕ | ♦ϕ | µX.ϕ | νX.ϕ,
where P is a proposition symbol, X is a variable symbol. The fixed-point formulas µX.ϕ and νX.ϕ are defined iff X is positive in ϕ. Denote the set of subformulas of ϕ by Sub(ϕ). We we use η to denote either µ or µ, and △ to denote or ♦.
We classify X as positive or negative in a given formula by structural induction:
• X is positive and negative in P ;
• X is positive in X ;
• if Y 6= X , X is positive and negative in Y ;
• if X is positive (negative) in ϕ, then X is negative (positive) in ϕ;
• if X is positive (negative) in ϕ and ψ, then X is positive (negative) in ϕ ∧ ψ, ϕ ∨ ψ, and △ϕ;
• if X is negative (positive) in ϕ and positive (negative) in ψ, then X is negative (positive) in ϕ→ ψ;
• X is positive and negative in ηX.ϕ.
While burdensome, we need to consider the positiveness and negativeness of variables to guarantee that the semantics for fixed-points formulas are welldefined. This contrasts with the classical µ-calculus, where it is common to suppose every formula is in negative normal form, and so we can set up the grammar in a way only positive variables occur. We cannot do the same on constructive semantics: For example, ¬♦¬ϕ is not equivalent to ϕ over constructive semantics.
An occurrence of a variable X in a formula ϕ is bound iff it in the scope of a fixed-point operator ηX . An occurrence of X is free iff it is not bound. A formula ϕ is closed iff it has no free variables. An occurrence of X in ϕ is guarded iff it is in the scope of some modality △. A formula ϕ is guarded iff, for all ηX.ψ ∈ Sub(ϕ), X is guarded in ψ. A formula ϕ is well-bounded iff, for all variables X occurring bounded in ϕ, X occurs only once and there is only one fixed-point operator ηX in ϕ. A formula is well-named iff it is guarded and well-bounded. Every formula is equivalent to a well-named formula. If ϕ is a well-named formula and ηX.ψ ∈ Sub(ψ), denote by ψX the formula ψ which is bound by the fixed-point operator ηX .

sections.heading: 3.1 Definition
sections.text:
Fix a bi-relational model M = 〈W,W⊥, ,⊑, V 〉, a world w ∈ W , and a wellnamed µ-formula ϕ. The evaluation game G(M,w |= ϕ) has two players: I and II. The two players will alternate the roles of Verifier and Refuter (abbreviated to V and R, respectively). The main positions are of the form 〈v, ψ〉 where v ∈ W and ψ ∈ Sub(ϕ). We also have auxiliary positions of the form 〈〈v〉, ψ〉, 〈[v], ψ〉, and 〈v, θ?θ′〉 where v ∈ W , △ψ, θ → θ′ ∈ Sub(ϕ). Each position is owned by one of I and II. At a position 〈v, ψ〉, the player in the role of V tries to prove that v |= ψ and the player in the role of R tries to prove that v 6|= ψ. The game begin at the position 〈w,ϕ〉, with I in the role of V and II in the role of R. The possible plays are described in Table 1. We explain below the plays available in evaluation game.
At the position 〈v, P 〉 there is no available move and the game ends; V wins iff v |= P , otherwise R wins. If v ∈ W⊥ and ψ ∈ Sub(ϕ), then V wins automatically at 〈v, ψ〉, overruling the other possibilities. At the position 〈v, ψ ∨ θ〉, V chooses one of 〈v, ψ〉 and 〈v, θ〉. They do so as only one of ψ and θ need to hold at v for ψ ∨ θ to hold at v. Similarly, at 〈v, ψ ∧ θ〉, R chooses one of 〈v, ψ〉 and 〈v, θ〉.
Let ηX.ψX ∈ Sub(ϕ); at 〈v, ηX.ψX〉 and 〈v,X〉, the players move to 〈v, ψX〉. When moving from 〈v,X〉 to 〈v, ψX〉, we say that the fixed-point ηX was regenerated. The ownership of these positions does not matter for the game, but we assign it to the player who does not want ηX to be regenerated infinitely often.
On a position of the form 〈v, ψ〉, R chooses v′ such that v v′, and then move the position 〈[v′], ψ〉; then, at 〈[v], ψ〉, R chooses v′′ such that v′ ⊑ v′′ and moves to 〈v′′, ψ〉. Similarly, on a position of the form 〈v,♦ψ〉, R chooses v′ such that v v′, and then move the position 〈〈v′〉, ψ〉; then, at 〈〈v′〉, ψ〉, V chooses v′′ such that v′ ⊑ v′′ and moves to 〈v′′, ψ〉. At a position of the form 〈v,¬ψ〉, R chooses v′ v and challenges V to show that M, v′ 6|= ϕ; that is, R modes to 〈v′, ψ〉 and the players exchange roles. Positions of the form 〈v, ψ → θ〉 is similar. In this case, R chooses v′ v and V chooses whether to show that M, v′ 6|= ψ or M, v′ |= θ; in case V chooses 〈v′, ψ〉, the players exchange roles. That is, R chooses v′ v and moves to 〈v′, ψ?θ〉, and then V chooses one of 〈v′, ψ〉 and 〈v′, θ〉; in case V chooses 〈v′, ψ〉, the players exchange roles.
Note that I and II always play the same role on vertices using the same formulas. That is, if I plays the role of V at 〈v, ψ〉 then they also play the role of V at 〈v′, ψ〉 for all v′ ∈ W . The same holds for the other combinations of players and roles. We can guarantee this by the positivity requirement on the fixed-point formulas. In particular, between positions 〈v,X〉 and 〈v′, X〉, the players must switch roles an even number of times.
Let ηX.ψX be the outermost infinitely often regenerated formula, the player on role of V wins iff η is ν. Formally, let ρ be an infinite play 〈w0, ϕ0〉, 〈w1, ϕ1〉, . . . with 〈w0, ϕ0〉 = 〈w,ϕ〉. Let η0X0, . . . , ηnXn be the fixed-point operators infinitely often regenerated in ρ. Let i be such that ηiXi.ψi is not a subformula of any other ηjXj.ψj . The player with the role of V on 〈w, ηiXi.ψi〉 wins ρ iff ηi is ν; similarly, R wins ρ iff ηi is µ. A player wins the game G(M,w |= ϕ) iff they have a win strategy. Since the evaluation games are Borel Gale–Stewart games, one of the players must have a winning strategy.

4 The collapse to modal logic over CS5 frames

sections.heading: 4.1 A short lemma
sections.text:
To prove the collapse over S5 frames, Alberucci and Facchini use the following result: ifM = 〈M,R,W 〉 is a Kripke model over an S5 frame, thenwRv implies w |= △ϕ iff v |= △ϕ. We cannot prove the same over CS5 frames, but the following Lemma will suffice:
Lemma 3. Let M = 〈W,W⊥, ,≡, V 〉 be a CS5 model and w ;≡ w′. Then
M,w |= △ϕ implies M,w′ |= △ϕ,
where △ ∈ { ,♦}.
Proof. Fix a CS5 model M = 〈W,W⊥, ,≡, V 〉. First note that ;≡ is a transitive relation. To see that, suppose w w′ ≡ v v′ ≡ u. By backward confluence, there is u′ such that w′ u′ ≡ v′. By the transitivity of and ≡, w u′ ≡ u.
Also note that the worlds seen in an evaluation game are ;≡-accessible from the previously seen worlds. That is, when if players have gone through a position 〈v, ψ〉 and later 〈v′, ψ′〉, then v ;≡ v′. This happens because and ≡ are reflexive relations and ;≡ is transitive.
Now, suppose w ;≡ w′ and M,w |= ♦ϕ. For all v w, there is u ≡ v such that M,u |= ϕ. Let v, v′ be such that w v ≡ w′ v′. By downward confluence, there is u such that v u ≡ v′. By the transitivity of , w u. So there is u′ w such that u ≡ u′ and M,u′ |= ϕ. As v′ ≡ u ≡ u′, v′ ≡ u′. So for all v′ w′ there is u′ ≡ v′ such that M,u′ |= ϕ. That is, M,w′ |= ♦ϕ.
Similarly, suppose w ;≡ w′ and M,w |= ϕ. Therefore w ;≡ u implies M,u |= ϕ. Let w′ ;≡ u′, then w ;≡ u′ by the transitiveness of ;≡. So M,u′ |= ϕ. Thus M,w′ |= ϕ.

sections.heading: 4.2 The collapse
sections.text:
We first show that the fixed-points for modal formulas can be reached in two steps. Our proof is by contradiction. This contradiction is not essential, but makes the proof easier to understand.
Lemma 4. Let M = 〈W, ,≡, V 〉 be a CS5 model and ϕ be a modal formula where X is positive and appears only once in ϕ. Then
‖µX.ϕ‖M = ‖ϕ2(⊤)‖M and ‖νX.ϕ‖M = ‖ϕ2(⊥)‖M .
Proof. We first show that ‖νX.ϕ‖ = ‖ϕ2(⊤)‖. Let M = 〈W,R, V 〉 be a Kripke model whereR is an equivalence relation, and νX.ϕ is a well-named µ-formula. We can also suppose that ϕ is of the form α(△β(X)) with △ ∈ { ,♦}.
We show that νX.ϕ is equivalent to ϕ2(⊤). As X is positive in ϕ(X), we have that ‖ϕ3(⊤)‖ ⊆ ‖ϕ2(⊤)‖. So we need only to show that ‖ϕ2(⊤)‖ ⊆ ‖ϕ3(⊤)‖.
For a contradiction, suppose that w ∈ ‖ϕ2(⊤)‖ and w 6∈ ‖ϕ3(⊤)‖. Then I has a winning strategy σ for the evaluation game G2 = G(M,w |= ϕ2(⊤)); and II has a winning strategy τ for the evaluation game G3 = G(M,w |= ϕ3(⊤)). We
use σ and τ to define strategies σ′ for I in G3 and τ ′ for II in G2. Remember that I starts on the role of V and II starts on the role of R.
We have the players use analogous strategies on both games. Suppose the players are in positions 〈v, ψ(⊤)〉 in G2 and 〈v, ψ(ϕ(⊤))〉 in G3. Both positions have the same owner, in the same role. That is, if I’s turn in some game, it is I’s turn in both games; and the owner’s role is V in some game, their role is V in both games. For example, suppose I is playing the role of R and the players are in positions 〈v,¬ψ(⊤)〉 and 〈v,¬ψ(ϕ(⊤))〉 in G2 and G3. If I plays σ(〈v,¬ψ(⊤)〉) = 〈v′, ψ(⊤)〉 in G2, they play 〈v, ψ(ϕ(⊤))〉 in G3. After there moves, I is playing the role of V in both games.
The players continue both games following the strategies described above until they get to a position of the form 〈v, P 〉 in both games; or they get to positions of the form 〈w′′,△β(⊤)〉 in G2 and 〈w′′,△β(ϕ(⊤))〉 in G3.
Case 1. Suppose the players are in a position 〈v, P 〉 in both games. Without loss of generality, suppose I is V and II is R. As σ is winning for I in G2, v ∈ ‖P‖. As τ is winning for II in G3, v 6∈ ‖P‖. And so we have a contradiction. A similar contradiction is reached if I is R and II is V.
Case 2. Suppose the players are in positions of the form 〈w′′,△β(⊤)〉 in G2 and 〈w′′,△β(ϕ(⊤))〉 in G3. Without loss of generality, suppose I is V and II is R. As τ is a winning strategy for II in G3, w′′ 6∈ ‖△β(ϕ(⊤))‖. Previously, the players must have been through some a position 〈w′,△β(ϕ(⊤))〉 in G2. As σ is a winning strategy for I in G2, w′ ∈ ‖△β(ϕ(⊤))‖. Note that, from the definition of the game, the reflexivity of and ≡, and the transitivity of ;≡, we have that w′ ;≡ w′′. By Lemma 3, w′′ ∈ ‖△β(ϕ(⊤))‖ since w′ ∈ ‖△β(ϕ(⊤))‖. We have our contradiction.
Either way, we conclude that ‖ϕ2(⊤)‖ ⊆ ‖ϕ3(⊤)‖. And so ‖νX.ϕ‖ = ‖ϕ2(⊥)‖.
In classical semantics, we can prove ‖µX.ϕ‖ = ‖ϕ2(⊥)‖ by a direct calculation. We cannot do the same in intuitionistic semantics as we cannot use the law of excluded middle. We have to prove it directly.
First, ‖ϕ2(⊥)‖ ⊆ ‖µX.ϕ‖ holds asX is positive in ϕ(X). If we suppose there isw such thatw ∈ ‖µX.ϕ‖ andw 6∈ ‖ϕ2(⊥)‖, we get a similar contradiction.
We are now able to show the constructive µ-calculus’ collapse to modal logic over µCS5 frames.
Theorem 5. Over models of CS5, every µ-formula is equivalent to a modal formula.
Proof. We argue by structural induction on µ-formulas. First, some of the easy cases. P is equivalent to a modal formula, as it is a modal formula. Suppose the µ-formulas ϕ and ψ are equivalent to modal formulas ϕ′ and ψ′, then ϕ∧ψ is equivalent to ϕ′ ∧ ψ′, ϕ → ψ is equivalent to ϕ′ → ψ′, ϕ is equivalent to ϕ′, ♦ϕ is equivalent to ♦ϕ′.
Now, the interesting cases. Similarly, νX.ϕ is equivalent to νX.ψ. By Lemma 4, νX.ψ is equivalent to ψ2(⊤), which is a modal formula. The same argument shows that µX.ψ is equivalent to ψ2(⊥).
Therefore every µ-formula is equivalent to a modal formula over models of IS5.

sections.heading: 5 Completeness for µCS5
sections.text:
In this section, we prove:
Theorem 6. The logic µCS5 is complete over CS5 frames. That is, for all closed µformula ϕ, µCS5 proves ϕ iff ϕ is true at all CS5 frames.
Proof. Let ϕ be a closed µ-formula. If µCS5 proves ϕ, then ϕ is true at all CS5 frames by Lemma 7. Now suppose ϕ is true at all CS5 frames. In particular, ϕ holds at all worlds of the canonical model. By the Truth Lemma, ϕ ∈ Λ for all µCS5-theory Λ. As µCS5 itself is a µCS5-theory, µCS5 proves ϕ.
We also prove completeness results for µIS5 and µGS5.

sections.heading: 5.1 Soundness
sections.text:
Lemma 7. Fix a µ-formula ϕ. Then if ϕ ∈ CS5 then ϕ holds over all CS5 frames.
Proof. The soundness arguments for the fixed-point axioms and induction rules are standard. See [BDF21] for the axioms in CS4. We only prove here the soundness of
5 := ♦ϕ→ ♦ϕ ∧ ♦ ϕ→ ϕ.
Fix a model M = 〈W,W⊥, ,≡, V 〉 over a CS5 frame. Suppose w w′ |= ♦ϕ. Let v, v′, u be such that w′ v ≡ v′ u. We want to show that there is u′ ≡ u such that u′ |= ϕ. By forward confluence, there is s such that v s ≡ u. By the transitiveness of , w′ s. So there is s′ ≡ s such that s′ |= ϕ. But ≡ is symmetric and transitive, so u ≡ s′. Therefore w′ |= ♦ϕ. We conclude w |= ♦ϕ→ ♦ϕ.
Now, suppose w w′ |= ♦ ϕ. We want to show that for all v w′ there is v′ ≡ v such that v′ |= ϕ. By our hypothesis, there is u such that w′ v ≡ u |= ϕ. But u u ≡ v′ so v′ |= ϕ. Therefore w′ |= ϕ. We conclude w |= ♦ ϕ→ ϕ.

sections.heading: 5.2 Truth Lemma for µCS5
sections.text:
The canonical model We say Γ is a µCS5-theory iff it is closed under under all rules of µCS5, and, if ϕ ∨ ψ ∈ Γ then ϕ ∈ Γ or ψ ∈ Γ. Denote by Γ♦ the set {ϕ | ♦ϕ ∈ Γ} and by Γ the set {ϕ | ϕ ∈ Γ}. Denote by Lµ the set of all closed µ-formulas.
Define the canonical model Mc := 〈Wc,W⊥c , c,≡c, Vc〉 by:
• Wc := {Γ | Γ is a µCS5-theory};
• W⊥c = {Lµ};
• Γ c ∆ iff Γ ⊆ ∆;
• Γ ≡c ∆ iff ∆ ⊆ Γ♦ and Γ ⊆ ∆; and
• Γ ∈ Vc(ϕ) iff P ∈ Γ.
Lemma 8. Mc is an CS5 model.
Proof. Since the subset relation ⊆ is a preorder, c is a reflexive and transitive relation over Wc. We need a little more work to show that ≡c is an equivalence relation over Wc:
• If ϕ ∈ Γ, then ♦ϕ ∈ Γ by T and MP. So Γ ≡c Γ. By Nec, Γ ⊆ Γ.
• Let Γ ≡c ∆ ≡c Σ. Then ∆ ⊆ Γ♦, Γ ⊆ ∆, Σ ⊆ ∆♦, and ∆ ⊆ Σ. Suppose ϕ ∈ Γ , then ϕ ∈ Γ and ϕ ∈ Γ, so ϕ ∈ Γ ⊆ ∆. Thus ϕ ∈ Σ. Suppose ϕ ∈ Σ, then ϕ ∈ ∆♦ and ♦ϕ ∈ ∆ ⊆ Γ♦. So ♦♦ϕ ∈ Γ. By 4 and Nec, ♦ϕ ∈ Γ and so ϕ ∈ Γ♦. Therefore Γ ≡c Σ.
• Let Γ ≡c ∆, then ∆ ⊆ Γ♦ and Γ ⊆ ∆. We want to show Γ ⊆ ∆♦, ∆ ⊆ Γ. Let ϕ ∈ Γ. By T and MP, ♦ϕ ∈ Γ. By 5, ♦ϕ ∈ Γ, so ♦ϕ ∈ Γ ⊆ ∆. Thus ϕ ∈ ∆♦. Now, suppose ϕ ∈ ∆ . So ϕ ∈ ∆ ⊆ Γ⋄. Thus ♦ ϕ ∈ Γ. By 5, ϕ ∈ Γ and so ϕ ∈ Γ. Therefore ∆ ≡c Γ.
Mc also satisfies the convergence requirement: Suppose Γ ≡c ∆ c Σ. Then ∆ ⊆ Γ♦, Γ ⊆ ∆, and ∆ ⊆ Σ. Let Φ be the closure under the deduction rules of Γ ∪ {♦ϕ | ϕ ∈ Σ}. Trivially, Γ ⊆ Φ and so Γ c Φ. Now we want to show that Φ ≡c Σ. If ϕ ∈ Σ then ♦ϕ ∈ Φ and so ϕ ∈ Φ♦. Suppose ϕ ∈ Φ . Then ϕ ∈ Φ and so ϕ ∈ Φ by T and MP. If ϕ ∈ Γ, then ϕ ∈ ∆ ⊆ σ and Γ ⊆ ∆. If ϕ 6∈ Γ, then there are ϕi ∈ Γ and ψj ∈ Σ such that ϕ1, . . . , ϕm,♦ψ1, . . . , ϕn ⊢ P . By Nec, each ϕi ∈ Γ too. So ψi ∈ ∆ ⊆ Σ. As ψi ∈ Σ, T implies that ♦ψi ∈ Σ. As Σ is closed under derivation rules, ϕ ∈ Σ. By T , ϕ ∈ Σ. Therefore Φ♦ ⊆ Σ. We conclude Φ ≡c Σ.
At last, we show that c preserves the truth of propositions. Suppose Γ c ∆ and Γ ∈ Vc(P ). So P ∈ Γ ⊆ ∆, and thus ∆ ∈ Vc(P ) too.
The Truth Lemma for modal formulas We first show the truth lemma for formulas without fixed-point operators. In particular, this implies that CS5 is complete over CS5 frames.
Lemma 9. For all formula ϕ without fixed-point operators,
Mc,Γ |= ϕ iff ϕ ∈ Γ.
Proof. The proof is by structural induction on modal formulas.
• If ϕ = P , then the lemma holds by the definition of Mc.
• If ϕ = ⊥, then the lemma holds by the definition of the semantics and of W⊥c .
• If ϕ = ψ1 ∧ ψ2, then
Γ |= ψ1 ∧ ψ2 iff Γ |= ψ1 and Γ |= ψ2
iff ψ1 ∈ Γ and ψ2 ∈ Γ
iff ψ1 ∧ ψ2 ∈ Γ.
• If ϕ = ψ1 ∨ ψ2, then
Γ |= ψ1 ∨ ψ2 iff Γ |= ψ1 or Γ |= ψ2
iff ψ1 ∈ Γ or ψ2 ∈ Γ
iff ψ1 ∨ ψ2 ∈ Γ.
Here we use that if ψ1 ∨ ψ2 ∈ Γ then ψ1 ∈ Γ or ψ2 ∈ Γ, as Γ is a µCS5 theory.
• Let ϕ := ψ1 → ψ2.
First suppose thatψ1 → ψ2 ∈ Γ. Let ∆ be a theory such that Γ c ∆ |= ψ1. By the induction hypothesis, ψ1 ∈ ∆. As Γ c ∆, ψ1 → ψ2 ∈ ∆. By MP, ψ2 ∈ ∆. So Γ |= ψ1 → ψ2.
Now suppose that ψ1 → ψ2 6∈ Γ. Take Σ to be the closure of Γ ∪ {ψ1} under the derivation rules. If ψ2 ∈ Σ, then there is χ ∈ Γ such that (χ ∧ ψ1) → ψ2 ∈ µCS5. And so χ → (ψ1 → ψ2) ∈ µCS5. As χ ∈ Γ, this means ψ1 → ψ2 ∈ Γ, a contradiction. Therefore ψ2 6∈ Σ. By the induction hypothesis, Σ |= ψ1 and Σ 6|= ψ2. As Γ c Σ, Γ 6|= ψ1 → ψ2.
• Let ϕ = ¬ψ. This case follows by the equivalence between ¬ψ and ϕ→ ⊥ over intuitionistic logic.
• Let ϕ = ψ.
First suppose that ψ ∈ Γ. Let Γ c ∆ ≡c Σ. Then ψ ∈ ∆ and ψ ∈ Σ. By induction hypothesis, Σ |= ψ.
Now suppose that ψ 6∈ Γ. Define Σ := Γ . By definition, ψ 6∈ Σ. By the induction hypothesis, Σ 6|= ψ. Now we show that Γ ≡c Σ. Γ ⊆ Σ follows by definition. Let θ ∈ Σ. Then θ ∈ Γ. By two applications of T , ♦θ ∈ Γ. So θ ∈ Γ♦. So Γ ≡c Σ. Therefore Γ c Γ ≡c Σ 6|= ψ, and thus Γ 6|= ψ.
• Let ϕ = ♦ψ.
First suppose that ♦ψ ∈ Γ. Let ∆ be a theory such that Γ c ∆. Furthermore, suppose ∆ is consistent. Let Σ be the closure under derivation rules of ∆ ∪ {ψ}. We want to show that ∆ ≡c Σ. ∆ ⊆ Σ holds by definition. Let θ ∈ Σ, then χ ∧ ψ → θ ∈ µCS5 for some χ ∈ ∆ . Thus χ → (ψ → θ) ∈ µCS5 and χ → (ψ → θ) ∈ µCS5. So (ψ → θ) ∈ ∆. By K , ♦ψ → ♦θ ∈ ∆. So ♦θ ∈ ∆.
Now suppose that ♦ψ 6∈ Γ. Γ is consistent (otherwise all formula is in Γ). Let ∆ be such that Γ ≡c ∆ and ψ ∈ ∆. By the definition of ≡c, ∆ ⊆ Γ♦, so ψ ∈ Γ♦. Therefore ♦ψ ∈ Γ, a contradiction. We conclude that for all ∆, if Γ c Γ ≡c ∆, then ψ 6∈ ∆. By the induction hypothesis, ∆ 6|= ψ. Therefore Γ 6|= ♦ψ.
The provable collapse We now show that any µ-formula is provably equivalent to a modal formula in µCS5.
We first prove a technical lemma showing that monotonicity for formulas without fixed-point operators is provable. We will be able to lift this restriction after we prove completeness for µCS5.
Lemma 10. Let Λ be a µCS5-theory. Suppose A → B ∈ Λ and ϕ(X) is a formula without fixed-point operators. If X is positive in ϕ(X), then ϕ(A) → ϕ(B) ∈ Λ. If X is negative in ϕ(X), then ϕ(B) → ϕ(A) ∈ Λ.
Proof. We prove this lemma using structural induction. We prove only the cases where X is positive, as the cases where X is negative are similar.
• For ϕ = P and ϕ = X , the result is immediate.
• Let ϕ = ψ ∨ θ. Then ψ(A) → ψ(B) ∈ Λ and θ(A) → θ(B) ∈ Λ. As [(ψ(A) → ψ(B)) ∧ (θ(A) → θ(B))] → (ϕ(A) → ϕ(B)) is a tautology, ϕ(A) → ϕ(B) ∈ Λ follows by MP.
• Let ϕ = ψ ∧ θ. Then ψ(A) → ψ(B) ∈ Λ and θ(A) → θ(B) ∈ Λ. As [(ψ(A) → ψ(B)) ∧ (θ(A) → θ(B))] → (ϕ(A) → ϕ(B)) is a tautology, ϕ(A) → ϕ(B) ∈ Λ follows by MP.
• Let ϕ = ψ. Suppose ψ(A) → ψ(B) ∈ Λ. Then (ψ(A) → ψ(B)) ∈ Λ by Nec. So ψ(A) → ψ(B) ∈ Λ by K and MP.
• Let ϕ = ♦ψ. Suppose ψ(A) → ψ(B) ∈ Λ. Then (ψ(A) → ψ(B)) ∈ Λ by Nec. So ♦ψ(A) → ♦ψ(B) ∈ Λ by K and MP.
• Let ϕ = ¬ψ. Then X is negative in ψ and ψ(B) → ψ(A) ∈ Λ. Since (ψ(B) → ψ(A)) → (¬ψ(A) → ¬ψ(B)) is a tautology, ¬ψ(A) → ¬ψ(B) ∈ Λ too.
• Let ϕ = ψ → θ. Then X is negative in ψ and positive in θ. So ψ(B) → ψ(A) ∈ Λ and θ(A) → θ(B) ∈ Λ. Since [(ψ(B) → ψ(A)) ∧ (θ(A) → θ(B))] → (¬ψ(A) → ¬ψ(B)) is a tautology, ϕ(A) → ϕ(B) ∈ Λ too.
Now, we show that fixed-points of modal formulas are equivalent to modal formulas over µCS5. This is a formal version of Lemma 4.
Lemma 11. If ϕ has no fixed-point operators, then νX.ϕ ↔ ϕ(ϕ(⊤)) ∈ µCS5 and µX.ϕ↔ ϕ(ϕ(⊥)) ∈ µCS5.
Proof. νX.ϕ → ϕ(νX.ϕ) holds by νInd. Since X is positive in ϕ, νX.ϕ → ⊤ implies ϕ(νX.ϕ) by Lemma 10. By MP, νX.ϕ→ ϕ(⊤). By the same argument, νX.ϕ → ϕ(ϕ(⊤)). Now, as ϕ(ϕ(⊤)) → ϕ(ϕ(ϕ(⊤))) is valid on any CS5 model, so is ϕ(ϕ(⊤)) → νX.θ. So νX.ϕ→ ϕ(ϕ(⊤)) ∈ µCS5.
The proof for µX.ϕ is similar.
Similar to how we proved Theorem 5, we use the Lemma 11 to prove:
Theorem 12. Any µ-formula is provably equivalent to a modal formula.
The Truth Lemma for fixed-point formulas With the provable collapse over CS5, we are now able to extend the Truth Lemma to all µ-formulas.
Lemma 13. For all closed µ-formula ϕ,
Mc,Γ |= ϕ iff ϕ ∈ Γ.
Proof. We prove this lemma by structural induction on formulas, as we proved Lemma 9. We omit cases already treated above.
• Let ϕ be νX.ψ(X). We want to show that Mc,Γ |= νX.ψ iff νX.ψ ∈ Γ.
By Lemma 11, νX.ψ is provably equivalent to some modal formula ϕ′. So ϕ↔ ϕ′ ∈ Γ. Thus:
νX.ψ ∈ Γ ⇐⇒ ϕ′ ∈ Γ ⇐⇒ Mc,Γ |= ϕ ′ ⇐⇒ Mc,Γ |= νX.ψ.
The first equivalence holds by MP, the second by completeness for CS5, and the last from the soundness of µCS5.
• Let ϕ be νX.ψ(X). By a proof similar to the paragraph above, we prove that Mc,Γ |= µX.ψ iff µX.ψ ∈ Γ.

sections.heading: 5.3 The fixed-point logics µIS5 and µGS5
sections.text:
The logic IS5 is obtained by adding to CS5 the axiomsN := ¬♦⊥, FS := (♦ϕ→ ψ) → (ϕ→ ψ), andDP := ♦(ϕ∨ψ) → ♦ϕ∨♦ψ. An IS5 frame is a CS5 frame with no infallible world. That 〈W,W⊥, ,≡〉 is a CS5 frame where W⊥ = ∅. The logic GS5 is obtained by adding to IS5 the axiomGD := (ϕ→ ψ)∨(ψ → ϕ). A GS5 frame is an IS5 which is locally linear: w u and w v imply u v or v u.
The logics µIS5 and µGS5 are obtained by adding fixed-point axioms and induction rules to IS5 and GS5, respectively. Note that all IS5 frames and GS5 frames are also CS5 frames. Therefore the µ-calculus also collapses to modal logic over IS5 frames and GS5 frames. Using the methods above, we can show:
Theorem 14. µIS5 is complete over IS5 frames.
Theorem 15. µGS5 is complete over GS5 frames.
The canonical models MµIS5c and M µGS5 c are respectively obtained by restricting the canonical model MµCS5c to consistent µIS5-theories and consistent µGS5-theories.
